document.title: Syllabus Cambridge International AS & A Level Marine Science 9693

00909FEF390044109776BCA664416D39.description: understand that due to the scale of many marine ecosystems, international cooperation and legislation is necessary, but not always possible (for example, non-universal sign-up to IWC moratorium or CITES), and the implications of this for conservation

4E3F5CC1544B4A02954302A484275ACB.description: the role of marine zoos and aquaria

5C11DD8846D04831A7FAB6B132EDA330.description: legislation both locally and globally, including CITES and IWC moratorium

D03FB5AE43D64E24BEC9571EDD0CA470.description: discuss strategies for conserving marine species, including:

D28BFA882F5048B4989C17CC5F9251B8.description: evaluate the viability of potential conservation projects from given information

DC2027BB37244DF6AF3E6B87FCFE3952.description: understand why invasive species pose a threat to native marine species and ecosystems

CFCD64FCE33144AD82936006F75BE19A.description: explain the meaning of the terms invasive species and endangered species, as defined by the IUCN

B84AF502B7E940FAA733F1AD82003FEE.description: understand how the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red List can assist in prioritising decisions on local, regional and global marine conservation projects

7580FB1442E948E5A9F37A63B49525E7.description: understand the need for conservation in terms of maintaining or enhancing biodiversity

4A4EEEC08B93460B8CAC787A9B278ADC.description: Conservation of marine ecosystems: Local, regional and global conservation efforts can go some way to reducing and even reversing harmful effects on marine ecosystems, but their implementation can sometimes be difficult and expensive.

BD50D51A1A454E59BBA7E1AAC8D18766.description: (PA) investigate the effect of pH on the loss of mass of empty mollusc shells

E4BA68E0D6604B69917DE4423F511A09.description: describe the impact of 9.3.2 on hard corals and shelled organisms

24ACA9B641D848CBB63C042ACE3564BA.description: describe how carbon dioxide reacts with water to form hydrogen ions and hydrogen carbonate ions, and, the impact this has on pH and carbonate ion availability

71A8FC11CB244F0796A86718B6423FED.description: explain the relationships between atmospheric carbon dioxide, dissolved carbon dioxide and acidity in the ocean, and understand how the oceans help to limit the increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations

B59E308E6FB64435AC990CBC49278E4A.description:
Ocean acidification: Carbon dioxide dissolves in sea water to form a weak acid, and increasing concentrations of atmospheric carbon dioxide therefore lead to a decrease
in the pH of sea water. This has damaging effects on many marine organisms, particularly those such as corals and molluscs whose skeletons
and shells contain calcium carbonate.

15299E50A2494B19B986FDDF2B38ECAB.description: describe the possible impacts of global warming on the marine environment, including sea level rise, coral bleaching, changes in the distribution of species and potential changes to the global circulation of sea water

E33210D01ECB42B8B354BB6E46AF7B00.description: discuss and evaluate the evidence for and against the hypothesis that human activity significantly contributes to global warming

75A8BA1B08004EDFB790FC8F782E392E.description: describe the evidence for global warming

E7BD20F56A924D06B106B732299367C5.description: explain how the enhanced greenhouse effect leads to global warming

463D45E0C93C41A9804C979FBAE2CE4A.description: describe how the natural greenhouse effect creates the Earth�s ambient temperature

98A6CC8CD31F463B84D29399F2BABBD6.description:
Global warming and its impact: The Earth�s atmosphere naturally contains carbon dioxide,
which produces the greenhouse effect, helping to maintain a temperature on Earth that
is suitable for life. However, increasing quantities of carbon dioxide, resulting at least partially from human activities, are enhancing the greenhouse effect and causing global warming. Global warming is already producing a range of negative impacts on the marine
environment.

EA2C5BD176BA40948AAC495B7ED6A90A.description: discuss strategies to limit the release of plastics and microplastics into the marine ecosystem

4BA7DDE641144F01B712463D2B9A47F7.description: risk to humans if plastics or toxins enter the human food chain

76DDD41DC7F8452A9A3AD6D76334DB6A.description: ingestion of plastics by marine organisms

D778A05A77BF459B815E440E144B1C2C.description: absorption of toxic compounds and their release after being taken up

F11715650EC042C2BF954739E9A7956B.description: transfer of microplastics along the food chain

44558E26775148F892722875A4C2790A.description: discuss the impacts of plastics and microplastics on the marine ecosystem, including:

3A01549FFE3B4962AD7E3D6F620A3A33.description: describe how most plastics do not biodegrade (non- biodegradable) but can be broken down to form secondary microplastic fragments, through the action of UV radiation, wind action and wave action, and how temperature affects this process

8FE3F3585B4B48D0A64FC9C8CC8275BC.description: understand that microplastics are plastic particles with a diameter of less than 5 mm and that there are two broad categories; primary microplastics and secondary microplastics

9F1C80CABC9E46BF8C0AC90AAD5D7235.description: explain the bioaccumulation of toxins and their biomagnification along food chains, including heavy metals in antifouling paint and mercury from the combustion of fossil fuels

98C1A3AC581F4724B0A443C2D9566E9B.description: fishing practices (including dredging and blast fishing)

B5406D2C832142B2AC40A7FBAEB0B2EB.description: explain the impacts on marine water quality, habitats, organisms and food webs of:

DA51C7D9F3014919894554478B37424C.description:
Ecological impacts of human activities: Human activities, whether taking place on land or at sea, frequently affect marine ecosystems. Oil spills, run- off from terrestrial industries and agriculture, and the use and disposal of plastics, have become serious issues, with potentially very significant and widespread effects.
Bioaccumulation of heavy metals and other toxins can also have considerable negative impacts.

782DA17099524837B5174712E71F0DF2.description: discuss the principal impacts of aquaculture, limited to habitat destruction, overexploitation of feedstocks, pollution, escape of cultured stock, introduction of (potentially) invasive species, spread of disease, competition for resources, reduction in the exploitation of native stocks, social impacts and economic impacts

B5BE2E9EFBA544EA954BB9B3F9065B38.description: explain the requirements for the long-term success of aquaculture projects, limited to availability of stock, availability of clean water, availability of feed, efficiency of use of feed, availability of labour, disease management, availability of location, market demand, access to market and return on investment

55D0EE00FC464430A698964E80818F22.description: outline the process of aquaculture including in salmon, marine mussels and shrimp

CB044D18E9BA4A5ABDC14A462056478A.description: describe intensive and extensive aquaculture techniques, with reference to named marine organisms

79FDBEF8B12F45E186D2FFC97A3654D2.description: Marine aquaculture: Increasingly, marine organisms are grown in controlled systems, as an alternative to harvesting from the wild. Aquaculture systems may be intensive or extensive, and both types can have a range of positive and negative social, economic and environmental impacts that should be considered when developing an aquaculture project.

6B39D816A1964DCA9518019AC7A88895.description: discuss the advantages and disadvantages of strategies for the rehabilitation of depleted stocks, including replanting mangroves, building artificial reefs and introducing cultivated stock to the wild

D038E550104C4AF184EF3589A8B24861.description: discuss the long-term and short-term sociological and economic impacts of, restrictions on fishing and of unrestricted fishing

31055ECC28504287834597E14948658D.description: discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the tools in 8.2.4, to include their effectiveness and impact on non-target species

E8389C056B03479CA1902DF704C365A1.description: consumer-orientated tools, including labelling, publicity campaigns and price tariffs

64937E4494A740CA906FAF64550E5665.description: imposition of fines, confiscation of boats and gear, imprisonment

66086F8E1A6F4D468D75ECCF13760BFB.description: monitoring, including air and sea patrols, satellite tracking, inspection of catch and fishing gear

E14C73621449436DAAE232D3FAB467AE.description: restriction of fishing intensity, including restrictions on the number of boats, boat and engine size, and the amount of fishing gear (for example, maximum net size, maximum number of traps)

CA868ADBDE424634ACB7F4D9DD388E2C.description: restrictions on the size of organism that can be retained

BE4BB6AE0C0842B2BCF2CA521EEE561A.description: restriction of method, including minimum mesh sizes and the compulsory use of rod-and-line

79AF74856AD844E6B75F2B812B674334.description: restriction of location, including refuge zones, no-take zones and marine protected areas (MPAs)

EDA101D03019458E8609B90E55250440.description: outline the principal tools used to ensure that fisheries are exploited on a sustainable basis, including:

7E7BBEEB4D0B4A689681A399ACB65DA1.description: describe the principal information needed to decide how best to exploit fisheries on a sustainable basis, limited to recruitment, growth, natural mortality, fishing mortality, age of reproductive maturity, fecundity and dependency on particular habitats

CDA72FCD073143DC8C1A696936586CA0.description: discuss the impact of modern fishing technology, including sonar, purse seine fishing, benthic trawling and factory ships, on populations and habitats

03BA987C82CD48C5A214F5C1D6B80007.description: explain the need for the sustainable exploitation of fisheries, with reference to a named marine organism

9FEF4AA292DD46E1840CCEB12735B89B.description:
Sustainable fisheries: Modern fishing methods can harvest so many fish that there is a danger that fish populations may be reduced beyond the point at which they can recover. Sustainable
exploitation can be achieved by collecting information about fish stocks, regulating fishing and rehabilitating depleted stocks.

F8C462ABE02A459C8B49B98CD5D37F3E.description: discuss the advantages and disadvantages of internal and external fertilisation, and subsequent investment in the care of offspring, with reference to tuna, sharks and whales

792FC1D64FBC469DA39605047834F824.description: outline the importance of different stages in the life cycle of sessile and non-sessile organisms

ADEEA44BD20B4BCF8B478C79C0DCEE44.description: describe the differences between simple and complex life cycles, to include marine mammals (simple) and crustaceans (complex), relating to the presence or absence of a larval stage and metamorphosis

43973AD4C07A4A1AAA4E48BBC9D3B5CD.description: describe metamorphosis, larval stage, sessile and non-sessile with reference to life cycles of marine animals

2E528CA2319A4F6C94E5A2919AEA506F.description:
Life cycles: Many species of marine organisms have complex life cycles with several different stages, in which one or more stages are adapted for dispersal. Marine mammals have simpler life cycles.

The female gametes of most invertebrates, and some vertebrates such as bony fish, are fertilised outside the body of the female, but fertilisation is
internal in mammals and sharks.

684BDFC590A445B1AA51EFADC1330E95.description: state the sites of aerobic respiration and anaerobic respiration in a cell

E6592F5857B84B6FA85733617673DD02.description: describe the structure of a mitochondrion, including matrix, outer membrane and inner membrane forming cristae

3328D05735744BE79AC803ABE9E16509.description: understand that in conditions where oxygen is limited or unavailable, most organisms also use anaerobic respiration which yields far less ATP per molecule of glucose (word and chemical equations are not required)

D4C842BF99554AE898FCE508019FE890.description: represent aerobic respiration using word and chemical equations glucose + oxygen ? carbon dioxide + water C6H12O6 + 6O2 ? 6CO2 + 6H2O

8D0C22842A3849878ECFEF299552D456.description: understand that aerobic respiration is the process that organisms use to release the energy they require in the form of ATP when oxygen is available

BAB8E84E6DFB4AA4BCAF358F604AF332.description: Respiration: Organisms require constant supplies of energy to maintain life processes. Respiration releases energy from organic nutrients in a usable form, as ATP.

A3E1A364C063418F9FAE6CA388F70E3E.description: explain that Endoriftia uses the energy from hydrogen sulfide to fix carbon thereby producing organic compounds such as glucose (word and chemical equations are not required)

1D5F864D0BE24592B8D8F117D19CA4A2.description: describe the symbiotic relationship between the giant tubeworm, Riftia, found at hydrothermal vents, and the chemosynthetic bacteria Endoriftia

B4494956658B42A9B274F5B883C101F8.description: understand that chemosynthetic bacteria at hydrothermal vents fix the energy into a form that other organisms can use, which allows the formation of a food chain

7DD031ECE8D2479E9665FCA7ED0013F1.description: describe chemosynthesis as the fixation of carbon using the chemical energy of dissolved substances; these substances include hydrogen sulfide, methane, hydrogen and iron

E019D1734BAC4D1CB5916191546611AD.description:
Chemosynthesis: Hydrothermal vents provide a habitat for a very unusual
community of living organisms adapted to the unique conditions found there. As there is no light, bacteria use energy from inorganic chemicals to produce organic substances.
This forms the basis of the food web. The bacteria live in symbiosis with tubeworms.

6CB38661489544FEBE33624BEEA390C4.description: (PA) investigate the effect of wavelength of light on the rate of photosynthesis (use of fresh water plants is acceptable)

93F175F3BE384C7083A9820C76A96BCA.description: describe and explain the effect of limiting factors of photosynthesis, including light intensity, wavelength of light, carbon dioxide concentration and temperature on the rate of photosynthesis

C7CB8AEC6C424419A6EB4FBC08A4BEF0.description: describe the light-independent stage (Calvin cycle) as the fixation of carbon dioxide using the enzyme rubisco and the ATP and reduced NADP formed during the light-dependent stage (details of intermediate compounds are not required)

3053E722C01A47ED8AEE7481EBCFB2AA.description: describe the light-dependent stage as the photoactivation of chlorophyll resulting in the photolysis of water and the transfer of energy to ATP and reduced NADP (details of cyclic and non-cyclic photophosphorylation are not required)

AE2C6D63A4B347A182B7BF91F5D6B4BE.description: interpret absorption spectra of chloroplast pigments and action spectra for photosynthesis

50E83B6C21674EEDBC123942EB8551F7.description: (PA) describe and use chromatography to separate and identify chloroplast pigments (reference should be made to Rf values)

5904F3DB33A34DCFA0FA712E9D61FEDB.description: relate the presence of accessory pigments, including xanthophylls and phycobilins, in marine producers to the penetration of different wavelengths of light

EB761EBEBB05476E8424916FD239DDEA.description: describe the role of chloroplast pigments (chlorophyll a and accessory pigments) in light absorption in the grana

D925DCE1A56B460384ECF1A650974438.description: state the sites of the light-dependent and the light-independent stages in the chloroplast

D0A0780ADEBD44CAB7E258B401C48CEC.description: describe the structures in a typical chloroplast, to include outer membrane, inner membrane, stroma, thylakoids, thylakoid membrane, thylakoid space and grana

777AE378AB5B4955BE84EFB76004E73E.description: explain that energy is transferred as ATP and reduced NADP from the light-dependent stage to the light-independent stage (Calvin cycle) and is used to produce organic molecules

63920ACC675646C4AC4D74440DEAF66F.description: understand that photosynthesis is a two-stage process, light-dependent and light-independent

BAC2705879AC4AC880A31745A48F5360.description: understand that photosynthesis is the process that nearly all marine producers use to fix carbon, and it can be summarised as: 6CO + 6H O ?li?ght? C H O + 6O

B233F1089A0A450BA95A619C4D98D052.description: describe the effect of wavelength on the penetration of light to different depths

22F91E7F5410455FAE801E54EB4D7729.description: differentiate between the terms wavelength, intensity and penetration in the context of light

45BFB12711294D2BB3E29958337B5DEE.description: understand that white light is composed of a range of colours, each with a different wavelength

63454F85F9C6428B87DF2A8084109C4B.description:
Photosynthesis: Photosynthesis is a two-stage process in which energy
is harvested from light by pigments, and then transferred to organic compounds. These compounds can be used
to synthesise biomass or to provide useful energy for life processes. Photosynthesis takes place in chloroplasts, whose structure enables these stages to take place efficiently.

If a requirement for photosynthesis is in short supply, it may act as a limiting factor, preventing the rate of photosynthesis from increasing.

3E360373F99F4C41BFB120BC329ECF0B.description: outline the processes of osmoregulation in e.g., salmon

C782CBC59D294876A9BB8DE256DE610D.description: explain the terms euryhaline and stenohaline with reference to salmon, marine mussels and tuna

DC672C9FDB7B44119EEF3188EE5D4AA5.description: explain the terms osmoconformer and osmoregulator with reference to marine mussels and tuna

D3FA26ECC82A4381BF7CD3E05960B059.description: explain why marine organisms may need to regulate their water content and ion content, with reference to the composition of sea water and of body fluids

A29D1326C609465DA31EA9BE4E0CACF4.description:
6.4 Osmoregulation: Sea water has a similar water potential to the body fluids of most marine organisms, and therefore many species do not need to regulate their water content. Other species are osmoregulators and control the water content of their bodies.

Most marine organisms can survive within only a small range of salinity, and are termed stenohaline. Euryhaline species can live in a range of salinities.
Salmon are an example of a euryhaline osmoregulator,
spending part of their life cycle in the sea and part in fresh water.

E1E9DBFD08514342BE8FCF3C59E60CE5.description: relate an organism�s method of gas exchange to its habitat and motility

476BEFC20072401E8408B5574171C6B1.description: describe gaseous exchange by simple diffusion, pumped ventilation and ram ventilation, in examples including coral polyps, grouper and tuna

765661BBE4244E14B2414FBBC1F663A1.description: discuss how surface area to volume ratio is dependent on the size and shape of an organism, and relate this to the need for specialised gaseous exchange surfaces and transport systems in larger animals

86CD4859B42C4E3D91ADEC69C22DF647.description: understand that the raw materials and waste products of respiration must be moved to and from the surface of organisms

67E3C2D8034E4F2DB2F7DE4E5F722DA9.description:
Gas exchange: Aerobic respiration requires oxygen and produces carbon dioxide. These two gases diffuse into and out of the organism, from and to its environment. This process is called gas exchange.
Smaller marine organisms often allow the gases to diffuse across their whole body surface, but most larger organisms have specialised surfaces across which gas exchange takes place. They may also have methods of ventilating these surfaces.

EF7100CA3D124589A06B0D0FE1AC377B.description: explain the movement of water between cells and solutions with different water potentials and explain the different effects on plant and animal cells

64C2A921EC8B441CB375FDFA62229DBB.description: (PA) investigate the effects of immersing plant tissues in solutions of different water potentials, using the results to estimate the water potential of the tissues

5965E85E9ADF4A1E944FC237E3A86ECB.description: (PA) investigate the effect of changing surface area to volume ratio on diffusion using agar blocks of different sizes

446311E3C7FB4823BC7E0038DA35380E.description: calculate surface areas and volumes of simple shapes (all formulae and relevant symbols will be provided) to illustrate the principle that surface area to volume ratio decreases with increasing size

4AC58711C10C40C280DF6D0111DEE75E.description: (PA) investigate diffusion and osmosis using plant tissue and non-living materials, such as Visking tubing and agar

D85E75318B644CEF988725791311290F.description: understand the concept of water potential and explain how dissolved solutes affect the water potential of a solution or cell (knowledge of solute potential is not required)

E35C1D5D28B8408FAE8F1C4764DEB21D.description: describe and explain the processes of diffusion, facilitated diffusion, osmosis and active transport

AFFEE5665D14475CA7A8D0CC9B8D40BE.description:
Movement of substances: Diffusion and facilitated diffusion across cell membranes are passive processes. Osmosis
is a particular type of diffusion involving water. Active transport however uses energy provided by the cell to move substances against their concentration gradient.

Water potential is a measure of the relative number of water molecules, and their freedom to move, in a solution. Water
diffuses down a water potential gradient and can move freely through cell membranes.

678B116DEB7643FB99F55CDB42C437CD.description: (PA) make observations, drawings and magnification calculations from unfamiliar structures or specimens

6E9E86548C0A473FA0940048AEB8C299.description: recall and apply the formula: magnification = image size � actual size

E896D989AA194D1896B8403686AEBF56.description: describe and interpret photomicrographs, electron micrographs and drawings of typical animal and plant cells

9D5EB6D9744F45DF9BCD7BDAD155C8D3.description: understand the selectively permeable nature of membranes and relate this to the transport (active and passive) of substances across a membrane

B89A2519255C4E50B01830576B8AB58A.description: describe the fluid mosaic model of membrane structure, including an outline of the structure and functions of phospholipids and proteins, limited to carrier and channel proteins

E0BDD8F937D949F1933FB6A8CC663418.description: recognise the following organelles and other cell structures and outline their functions:

13BF33343AED4A31B24770BDFD096781.description:
General cell structure: All living organisms are formed of units called cells, which have many features in common.
Each cell is separated from its immediate environment by the cell surface membrane, and contains genetic material and organelles within the
cytoplasm. An understanding of the structure of the cell surface membrane enables us to understand its functions.

We use microscopes to visualise cells. The images produced can be studied and interpreted to increase understanding of cell structure.
